ai_diag.summary: A 38-year-old woman presents with a productive cough, frontal forehead pain suggestive of sinus involvement, and an audible rumbling noise on deep inspiration. She has no prior diagnostic workup, follows a paleo diet, exercises moderately, and reports increased stress and anxiety at work.

ai_exam.summary: Acute frontal sinusitis typically presents with frontal headache, facial pain/pressure worsened by bending forward, purulent nasal discharge, nasal congestion, and may follow a viral upper respiratory infection. Acute bronchitis presents with a cough (often productive), chest discomfort, wheezing or rhonchi on auscultation, and sometimes low-grade fever. Both conditions are usually viral, but bacterial causes can require targeted therapy. Clinical evaluation focuses on history and physical exam; imaging and laboratory studies are reserved for atypical, severe, or prolonged cases.

patient.mental_exercises: reading before bed, sporadic yoga classes
patient.mental_health: stressed about work, anxious when thinking about career path
patient.symptoms: coffing, forehead pain, rumbling noise when deep breathing

ai_diag.summary: A 45-year-old man presents with epigastric burning pain that worsens after eating, occasional regurgitation of acidic fluid, and nighttime discomfort. He has a history of occasional NSAID use for back pain and reports moderate alcohol consumption. Symptoms have persisted for 3 months despite OTC antacids.

options: Helicobacter pylori testing (stool antigen or breath test)
ai_exam.summary: GERD typically presents with heartburn, regurgitation, and sometimes dysphagia. Peptic ulcer disease may present with epigastric pain that improves with food (duodenal) or worsens with food (gastric). Gastritis often includes nausea and bloating. Initial evaluation focuses on symptom pattern and response to empiric therapy, with diagnostic testing reserved for alarm symptoms or treatment failure.

patient.symptoms: epigastric burning, acid regurgitation, nighttime discomfort

ai_diag.summary: A 52-year-old female presents with 6 weeks of progressively worsening low back pain radiating to the right buttock, aggravated by prolonged standing and lifting. She reports no bowel/bladder changes but notes occasional right leg tingling. She works as a nurse and has a history of intermittent back pain episodes.

ai_exam.summary: Lumbar strain typically presents with localized pain and muscle spasms. Radicular symptoms suggest nerve root compression from disc herniation or stenosis. Red flags include bowel/bladder dysfunction, progressive neurological deficits, or history of malignancy. Most cases are mechanical and improve with conservative management; imaging is reserved for red flags or persistent symptoms.

patient.previous_tests: lumbar X-ray 2 years ago (mild degenerative changes)
patient.symptoms: low back pain radiating to right buttock, occasional right leg tingling

patient.mental_health: having quick mood changes when playing competitive games online

ai_diag.summary: A 29-year-old sedentary male with a diet high in processed foods presents with new-onset vertical diplopia and itchy eyes, without prior diagnostic testing. He also reports mood swings during competitive online gaming but no other systemic or neurological history.

ai_exam.summary: Differentiation of trochlear (CN IV) palsy, myasthenia gravis, orbital myositis, and allergic conjunctivitis depends on a combination of targeted ocular motility testing, neuromuscular function assays, orbital imaging, and allergy evaluation. Trochlear palsy is characterized by incomitant vertical diplopia and extorsion corrected by head tilt; myasthenia gravis shows fatigable ptosis/ophthalmoplegia with improvement on ice pack or edrophonium testing; orbital myositis causes painful motility restriction and extraocular muscle enlargement on imaging; allergic conjunctivitis presents with itching, papillae, chemosis on slit-lamp exam and positive allergy tests.
options: Ocular motility exam with head-tilt test

selected_exams: Ocular motility exam with head-tilt test

ai_diag.summary: A 19-year-old female ballet dancer presents with pain localized to the hallux (including the nail region) and the plantar aspect of the foot, likely related to repetitive stress and biomechanical overload. She has no prior diagnostic workup and reports a vegetarian diet, daily ballet practice, and anxiety about performances.

ai_exam.summary: The patient’s foot pain may arise from inflammation at the plantar fascia insertion (plantar fasciitis), overload of the metatarsal heads (metatarsalgia), or mechanical/degenerative changes around a hallux valgus deformity. A combination of imaging studies, functional assessments, and targeted diagnostic procedures can help confirm the primary pain generator, evaluate severity, and guide optimal management.

patient.mental_health: anxious about public ballet performances and career development
patient.symptoms: pain the foot hallux and nails, pain the plantar region of the foot
has noticed a small vertical double vision, itchy eyes, dry eyes
patient.mental_health: gets irritated about the vision issues

ai_diag.summary: A 39-year-old man presents with new-onset small vertical diplopia accompanied by itchy, dry eyes, causing significant frustration. Given the ocular surface symptoms alongside misalignment, both surface disease and neuromuscular or endocrine-related causes should be explored.
options: Superior oblique palsy (cranial nerve IV palsy)

selected_diagnoses: Superior oblique palsy (cranial nerve IV palsy)

ai_exam.summary: The differential includes surface disease (dry eye, allergic conjunctivitis) versus neuromuscular and orbital causes of diplopia and eyelid findings (superior oblique palsy, ocular myasthenia gravis, thyroid orbitopathy, decompensated phoria). A structured approach with anterior segment evaluation, tear assessment, allergy workup, ocular motility/alignment tests, neuromuscular fatigue testing, serologies, thyroid studies, and orbital imaging will help distinguish these entities.
options: Slit lamp examination with fluorescein staining and tear break-up time
Allergy testing (skin prick or conjunctival provocation)
Cover-uncover and alternate cover tests with prism measurement
Park’s three-step test for superior oblique palsy
Ice-pack test for ocular myasthenia gravis

selected_exams: Allergy testing (skin prick or conjunctival provocation)
